any pond in an urban setting is going to receive a fair amount of runoff especially during high rainfall events and that will be another input of nutrients from urban sources around that pond such as lawn fertilizer
some cities have adopted plans to deal with waterfowl and i think grand island ought to do that if they want to sustain a decent fish population in that lake

in many cases that helps to avoid situations like what happened at pier park pond unless the algae complexes are just too abundant and there's too much nutrients and algae growth and those aerations and fountains are not able to keep up
pier park pond is by far the worst in grand island
